conclusion: The graphs show velocity vs. time for two objects A and B, both starting at the same position at t = 0.
Object A follows a straight line (constant acceleration) and Object B follows a curved path (varying acceleration).
To find when the objects are farthest apart, analyze their relative displacement: |position_A - position_B|.
Position is the integral of velocity with respect to time: x_A(t) = ∫v_A(t)dt and x_B(t) = ∫v_B(t)dt.
Both objects start at the same position (origin) and have positive velocities throughout the time interval.
Object A has greater velocity than B initially, and at time t₁, object B's velocity reaches its minimum.
The graphs intersect at time t₂ (the red dot in the second image).
The separation increases when their relative velocity is non-zero and reaches maximum when relative velocity changes sign.
At t₂, their velocities become equal, A is ahead of B, and after t₂, B's velocity exceeds A's, reducing separation.
The two objects are farthest apart at time t₂, marked by the intersection of their velocity-time graphs.
